thread.title: 24 Facts You Didn't Know About The Movie "La Bamba"
thread.title_full: 24 Facts You Didn't Know About The Movie "La Bamba"

author: Norberto Briceño
title: 24 Facts You Didn't Know About The Movie "La Bamba"
text:
View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10259474 2. Ritchie’s real-life sister, Connie Limos , was on-set when the infamous “coin toss” scene was filmed, where Ritchie wins a coin toss to fly alongside The Big Bopper and Buddy Holly. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com She sobbed uncontrollably and threw herself at Lou Diamond Phillips screaming, “Why did you have to go? Why did you have to go?”
ID: 10259506 3. According to Connie Limos, the film provided closure for the Valenzuela family. They were “finally able to accept…let go.” View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10259597 4. The mid-air plane collision at the beginning of the film occurred in real-life on January 31, 1957. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com The debris crashed into the schoolyard of Pacoima Junior High School, which ultimately killed 8 people , and injured 75 others . Most of the victims were school children.
Ritchie lost his best friend in the accident, and would cause him to develop a fear of flying. Ritchie was not at school that day, as he was at his grandfather’s funeral .
ID: 10259705 5. Ritchie’s real-life mother, Concepcion Reyes, appeared in the film during the first family party. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com She died three months after the film’s release.
ID: 10259792 6. Esai Morales had originally auditioned for the role of Ritchie Valens, while Lou Diamond Phillips had auditioned for the darker role of Bob. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com The director’s brother, Daniel Valdez , who was also an associate producer, recommended Phillips for the role of Ritchie.
ID: 10259891 7. Lou Diamond Phillips was originally told that he would audition for a musical about the life of Frankie Valli . View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10260380 8. In the original script, Ritchie’s older brother Bob was the lead of the film . View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10260384 9. Even though Lou Diamond Phillips played Esai Morales’ younger brother in the film, he was actually the older of the two. Morales was 23 , and Phillips was 24. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10260626 10. While it’s stated in the film that Steve, Ritchie’s dad, drunk himself to death, the real Steve died from life-long complications after coming into contact with mustard gas during the first World War. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10260782 11. Lou Diamond Phillips was a stage actor in Fort Worth, Texas when he first auditioned for the film in Dallas . He was flown to Hollywood two weeks later and was cast as Ritchie. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261120 12. Rosanna de Soto, who played Connie, the mother of Ritchie and Bob, was only 12 years older than Lou Diamond Phillips and Esai Morales. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261066 13. Despite the mainstream, global appeal of the song “La Bamba,” Los Lobos for a time “didn’t totally enjoy bringing it out at concerts.” View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261187 14. According to Lou Diamond Phillips, the family was on-set everyday and they constantly referred to him as “Ritchie.” View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261094 15. The “Northern California” fields that the Valenzuela family are working in at the beginning of the film are actually in San Jose, California. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261201 16. Writer/Director Luis Valdez was originally supposed to just write the script, with Taylor Hackford (who directed Ray in 2004) at the helm as director. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com But even though Hackford had been with the project since the beginning, he became too expensive to hire and stayed on as Executive Producer. So Valdez took over.
ID: 10261302 17. The idea of a Ritchie Valens biopic was first pitched back in the early ’70s to music label A&M Records, but they turned it down. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com It was actually Luis Valdez’s brother, actor/musician/producer Daniel Valdez and Taylor Hackford who first pitched the idea.
ID: 10261671 18. Daniel Valdez had thought about putting Ritchie Valens’ story on the stage as a musical . View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261694 19. He also spent five to six years researching Valens’ life, from collecting articles to tracking down the Valenzuela family, who were extremely wary at first about the project. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261695 20. Valdez originally wanted to cast Emilio “El Indio” Fernandez, a pioneer of the golden age of Mexican cinema, for the role of El Curandero , but he died due to a motorcycle accident. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com The role went to Felipe Cantu, a longtime member of Luis Valdez’s El Teatro Campesino, in what would be his last role ever.
ID: 10261402 21. Los Lobos were working on their second album By the Light of the Moon at the same time they were doing work for La Bamba . View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com They had two studios at Sunset Sound in Hollywood, one for their album and another for the film, and would constantly have to run back and forth between the two.
ID: 10261552 22. While the film is completely in English, there were a few theaters that showed the film with Spanish subtitles and Spanish dubbing , which raked in nearly $400,000 at the box office. View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261582 23. Los Lobos appear in the film as the band playing “La Bamba” when Ritchie and Bob go to Tijuana. View this image ›
ID: 10267055 24. The soundtrack for La Bamba , along with the single, peaked at #1 on Billboard’s Hot 100 in September, 1987. The album was also certified double platinum . View this image ›
Colombia Pictures / Via youtube.com ID: 10261622
